title: One last chance
text:
Mark Massoglia , Daily Tribune Media 9:03 p.m. CDT October 15, 2015 Local teams need to win to qualify for playoffs Buy Photo Wisconsin Rapids quarterback Ben Olson sheds the last Marshfield defender standing between him and a 64-yard-touchdown run as Rapids went on to score a late touchdown to beat Marshfield 42-35 in a wild game in Marshfield, Friday. The Marshfield defender is Chase Freeck. Olson later scored the winning touchdown. Wisconsin Rapids quarterback Benjamin Olson sand the Raiders can become playoff eligible with a win over Oshkosh North Friday. (Photo: Dan Young/Daily Tribune Media) Buy Photo CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
WISCONSIN RAPIDS â€” For the Wisconsin Rapids, Port Edwards, Nekoosa, Pittsville and Adams-Friendship football teams, Week 9 is the most important of the season. 
Other games during the season likely had higher priority, but this week means the most in terms of postseason aspirations. Simply put, a win will make all five teams playoff eligible, while a loss will bring the 2015 season to a close. 
"It's a double-edged sword in my opinion," Nekoosa coach Jason Becker said. "If you hype a game like this up too much it can backfire, but if you don't make it clear what the game means, you aren't preparing the kids either. 
"We haven't hid from what the Westfield game means for us. It's not up to anyone other than us whether or not we win the game and make ourselves playoff eligible." 
Only Rapids is at home, making the task at hand slightly more difficult for the other four teams. On the plus side, all but Pittsville are playing teams that have struggled all season. 
The Panthers travel to Stratford a team they haven't beaten in quite some time, but anything can happen. Pittsville has, however, won three straight Marawood games and four of their last five games. Port Edwards, Nekoosa and A-F are playing teams with a combined three wins. 
"This is certainly a game you hope to win and you need to be prepared," Becker said. "I'm sure Westfield would love to beat us and end our season." 
Despite riding a three-game VFA-South skid, the Raiders are in a position to make the postseason due in part to a new conference rule that counted the second VFA crossover game as a league game. 
"When it was discussed, I thought was a good idea and certainly wouldn't hurt any teams and it has helped us," Rapids coach Tony Biolo said. 
The Raiders also caught a break when they got a win back from Oshkosh West. The Wildcats played with an ineligible player were forced for forfeit the games that the player participated in. Buy Photo 
Nekoosa senior Tarek Tuttle and the Papermakers need to beat Westfield Friday to earn playoff eligibility. (Photo: Megan McCormick/Daily Tribune Media) 
"After the Fond du Lac loss the kids were down, because we thought we were eliminated from the playoffs," Biolo said. "Since we got the news about West, the kids have refocused and are working hard to win our last football game. For us, the playoffs start a week early." 
The vision is clear for these five teams. Now the task is to put it all together for one last game. The 48 minutes they play Friday will determine whether they get another week of practice and a 10th game. 
Mark Massoglia can be reached at 715-423-7200, ext. 4736 or mark.massoglia@gannettwisconsin.com . Follow him on Twitter @markmazzy . 
MUST WIN GAMES 
Oshkosh North (5-3, 4-3 VFA-South) at Wisconsin Rapids (4-4, 3-3 VFA-South) 
Port Edwards (4-4, 2-2 CWC-10) at Tigerton/Marion (1-7, 1-3 CWC-10) 
Nekoosa (3-5, 2-2 SCC) at Westfield (1-7, 0-4 SCC) 
Pittsville (4-4, 3-3 Marawood) at Stratford (6-2, 4-2 Marawood) 
Adams-Friendship (5-3, 2-2 SCC) at Wisconsin Dells (1-7, 1-3 SCC) 
All games are 7 p.m. Friday Read or Share this story: http://wrtnews.co/1RLjXUY TOP VIDEOS
